Vocabularies.Definition: (infml) very active or busy 繁忙；活动多
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  I've been on the go all week, preparing my thesis.

Vocabularies.Definition: vi. deal successfully (with sb. / sth. difficult)  （成功地）对付；妥善处理
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Health psychologists study how people cope with stress.

Vocabularies.Definition: begin (a task); start (doing sth.) 开始；着手
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The school authorities must set about finding solutions to the campus security problems.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt.    free (sth.) from knots, complexities, etc. 解开…的纠结，理顺
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  She untangled her hair from the hair-drier.

Vocabularies.Definition: large amounts/a large amount of 许多的，大量的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The key to staying healthy and strong when backpacking is to eat large quantities of energy-rich foods.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  the state of being idle 闲散；无所事事
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Idleness is the parent of all vice.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt.  make a slave of (sb.) 使成为奴隶，奴役
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Her beauty enslaved many young men.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.   puzzling 令人困惑的；费解的 bewilder vt.   puzzle; confuse 使困惑；使糊涂
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  I don't know how to solve this bewildering question.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  (pl millennia or millenniums) period of a thousand years 一千年
gradually reduce the amount of (sth. valuable); damage or destroy 吞噬；侵蚀；毁坏
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  All these car expenses are eating into our savings.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.    汽车
n.   （单复同）飞机；航空器
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The goal of air traffic control is to minimize the risk of aircraft collisions.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.     taking or needing much time 耗费时间的 e.g.  Starting a new business, however small, is a time-consuming exercise.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  crossing the Atlantic; on or from the other side of the Atlantic 横越大西洋的；在（或来自）大西洋彼岸的
n.   organized journey or voyage with a particular aim 远行；探险；远征 e.g.  Scott died while he was on an expedition to the Antarctic in 1912.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.   conference of members of a profession, political party; generally accepted social behavior 大会；惯例，常规 e.g.   She was a speaker at the Railway Workers' Convention in 1956.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: vi.  work hard and untiringly; move with difficulty or pain 辛苦地劳作；艰难地行动 e.g.  We toiled away all afternoon to get the house ready for our guests.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: in actual fact; really 事实上；实际上 e.g.  Some famous private schools are theoretically open to the public, but in reality are attended by those who can afford the fees.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: v.   increase in number or quantity; add a number to itself a particular number of times 增加；乘 e.g.  The weeds just multiplied, and before long the garden was a jungle.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt. take care of the appearance of (oneself) by dressing neatly  梳妆 e.g.  He groomed himself carefully in front of the mirror.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  便携式电脑
n.   set of symptoms which together indicate a particular disease or abnormal condition 综合病症；综合症状
n.    heavy load 负担，重负 e.g.  Some farmers are complaining about the heavy burden of taxation.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  传真件；传真系统
n.  an electronic communication system in which spoken messages are recorded and stored for later playback for the intended recipient 语音邮件
n.   软件
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  He is applying for a position of software engineer.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.   小故障，失灵
n.  a small part, bit, amount or proportion (of sth.) 小部分，一点儿，少许
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Only a small fraction of the population lived in that remote area.

Vocabularies.Definition: 大量涌入
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Many football fans poured into the stadium to have a look at their favorite football players.

Vocabularies.Definition: abbr.  compact-disc read-only memory 光盘只读存储器
v. increase rapidly in numbers; produce new growth or offspring rapidly （数量）激增；（迅速地）增殖
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  In recent years commercial, cultural, travel and other contacts have proliferated between Europe and China.

Vocabularies.Definition: 少数，少量；一把
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Only a handful of graduates have not found jobs so far.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  newspaper or periodical, esp. one that is serious and deals with a specialized subject 日报；(学术) 期刊
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  the Journal of Medical Science

Vocabularies.Definition: n.   出版（物）；发表，公布
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The collection of the theses is ready for publication.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.   (of a degree, rank, etc.) given as an honor（指学位、级别等）荣誉的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  He's the honorary chairman of the committee.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. person in charge of a museum, an art gallery, etc. （博物馆、美术馆等的）馆长
n.  scientific study of insects 昆虫学
a.  involving comparison or comparing 比较的；相比的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.   Some sociologists have carried out large-scale historical-comparative studies.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. scientific study of the structure, form and distribution of animals  动物学
be equal to; add up to 相当于；总计
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  In 1959 the combined value of U.S. imports and exports amounted to less than 9 percent of the country's gross domestic product.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  very small in size or amount 极小的；极少的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Only a minute amount of money is needed.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. (usu. pl)（某学科的）知识边缘，（探索活动的）新领域；边境
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  To open up the space frontier, NASA will try to lower the cost of access to Earth orbit.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  pressure or worry resulting from mental or physical distress, difficult circumstances, etc. 压力，重压  vt. put stress, pressure, or strain on 加压力于；使紧张
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  There is enough evidence to suggest that job stress may increase a man's risk of dying from heart disease.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.   state of being economically successful; state of being successful or rich （经济的）繁荣；成功，富足
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  War brings no prosperity to the great mass of ordinary citizens.

Vocabularies.Definition: v.    do sth. for (sb.) as a favor or small service（为…）效劳； 帮（…的）忙
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  If you ever need help with the baby-sitting, I'd be happy to oblige.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  lack of satisfaction 不满足；不满意
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.   The strikers were a sign of discontent with poor pay.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.    quantity that is more than enough; plenty 丰富；丰裕
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The visitor to Oxford has an abundance of sights to see.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.    bewilderment or embarrassment 惶惑；迷乱
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  I explained the question to him three times, but there was still a look of confusion on his face.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.    简略的表达方式；速记（法）
a.   temporarily without a paid job 未被雇用的；失业的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  He was unemployed for two months after leaving college.

Vocabularies.Definition: ad.  外围地；边缘地；次要地 peripheral   a.
n.   经济；经济制度；节约
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  His views on knowledge economy have been accepted with unanimity.

Vocabularies.Definition: (forecast or forecasted) vt.  tell in advance; predict 预报；预测
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The means of forecasting natural disasters, such as floods, and hurricanes, have improved immensely as science and technology have advanced.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  decided by oneself, without being influenced or ordered by other people 自己强加的，自愿承担的
n. person who offers to do sth. without being compelled or paid 自愿者；志愿兵
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Some students served as volunteers to help the old and disabled in the community in their spare time.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  way of seeing or understanding sth.; ability to notice and understand things 看法，观念；感知，感觉
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Aesthetics is a branch of philosophy concerned with the essence and perception of beauty and ugliness.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  社会学
ad.   不均衡地；不平坦地；不平整地 uneven  a.
n.   unmarried people 未婚的人们
n.   厮守“空巢”者（尤指子女不在身边的人）
a. 学龄前的；学前的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  pre-school children

Vocabularies.Definition: vt.  care for and educate (a child); encourage the growth of (sth.); nourish 养育；培育；滋养
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Parents want to know the best way to nurture and raise their children to adulthood.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.（单复同） child or children of a particular person or couple 孩子，子女
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Heredity is the process of transmitting biological traits from parents to offsprings through genes.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  性别
n.    instrument or device for a specific purpose 用具；器具
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The Energy Department has set efficiency standards for new home appliances.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  causing fear; shocking; terrible 骇人听闻的；令人震惊的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  When will this appalling war end?

Vocabularies.Definition: n.    分布；分配
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The study of animal distribution is called zoogeography.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. (instance of) extreme scarcity of food in a region 饥荒
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  China has succeeded in feeding its people; national attention to equity, agriculture, and birth control has significantly reduced the threat of famine.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. found or distributed over a large area 遍布的；大面积的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The landscape of the American West was dramatically altered during the 20th century as a result of the widespread construction of dams along major rivers.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt.  cause (sth.) to occur or arouse (a feeling, etc.) 使产生；引起（某种感情等）
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.   People's concern over genetically modified food has provoked a global debate that shows no sign of ending soon.

Vocabularies.Definition: 各种的；各种各样的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  People change their mind for a variety of reasons.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  (of computer) fixed number of binary digits, often representing a single character 字节；位组
a.    state of being  pleased or satisfied 满意；满足
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Your approval gives me much gratification.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt.  make (sth.) more efficient and effective 使合理化，使效率更高；使成流线型
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Corporate mergers can result in job losses because management combines and streamlines departments within the newly merged companies.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  (process of) growing; development 生长；发展
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The area has seen a rapid population growth.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  doorkeeper 看门人，看守人
a.  of the home, household or family; of or inside a particular country 家庭的；家务的；国内的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Police and hospital records indicate that the majority of victims of domestic violence are women.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 儿童保育；儿童照管
a.   connected to and controlled by a computer 联机的，在线的
n. tradesman who sells by retail 零售商
n.   an assembly, place, radio program etc. for the discussion of public matters or current questions 论坛；讨论会；（广播、电视的）专题讨论节目
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The school authorities will provide a forum where problems can be discussed.

Vocabularies.Definition: appear, develop, grow, etc. quickly or suddenly 迅速发展（或生长）；突然出现
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  New professional training schools sprang up all over the country.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  producing no result; useless; pointless 无效的；无用的；无意义的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  It was futile to continue the negotiations.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt.  turn (sb./sth.) aside from a course, direction, etc. into another 使转向；转移
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Some dams divert the flow of river water into a pipeline, canal, or channel.

Vocabularies.Definition: vi.   (arose, arisen)   appear; become evident 出现；呈现
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Challenging ethical issues have arisen in science and medicine.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  lack of sth. needed; deficiency 缺少；不足；短缺
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The world is facing the prospect of water shortages caused by population growth, uneven supplies of water, pollution, and other factors.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.   too large an amount 过量，过度
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  A surfeit of food makes one sick.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt. push or force  into a small place 将…塞入， 硬塞进
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  It's dangerous for too many people to be crammed into a bus.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.   sweets or chocolate 糖果；巧克力
vt.  avoid (sth. unpleasant or unwanted); manage not to do (sth. which should be done) 躲开，避开；逃避
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The released criminal always tries to evade the police.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.    (usu. pl) boundaries; limits; borders 范围；界限；边界
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  This is outside the  confines of human knowledge.

Vocabularies.Definition: ad.  in a reasonable way; moderately 合理地；适度地 reasonable   a.
disconnect (electricity, etc.)  关，切断（电源等）
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  Be sure to switch off the lights when you leave home.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  手机
命定；注定
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  He thought that he was doomed to spend the rest of his life in a wheelchair.
